section.p: Higher education operates in a quickly changing, progressively more globalized, cosmopolitan, and interconnected world (Bauman, 2000, Globalization: The Human Consequences. New York/Chichester: Columbia University Press; Appiah, 2006, Cosmopolitanism: Ethics in a World of Strangers. New York: W.W. Norton & Co; Zuckerman, 2013, Rewire: Digital Cosmopolitans in the Age of Connection. New York: W. W. Norton & Company). At the same time, substantive inequalities between people and places mean that this connectivity and knowledge is unevenly spread (Hallberg Adu, 2014, What is the opposite of a knowledge society? A critical reflection from Ghana. In Amoah, L. (ed.), Impacts of the Knowledge Society on Economic and Social Growth in Africa. IGI Global). For our students, the future leaders of this unequal world, critical reasoning becomes a key skill, and perhaps especially so for students in the Global South. This paper argues that digital humanities (DH) can provide both a theoretical framework for decolonizing the academy and technological solutions to hurdles in this process. The paper argues that assignments, their theoretical underpinnings, and implementation are key to decolonizing higher education. It describes three accessible technology-driven assignments with DH pedagogy created for diverse classrooms at Ashesi University in Ghana and discusses their outcomes.

div.p: Higher education operates in a quickly changing, progressively more globalized, cosmopolitan, and interconnected world (Bauman, 2000; Appiah, 2006; Zuckerman, 2013). At the same time, substantive inequalities between people and places mean that this connectivity and knowledge is unevenly spread (Hallberg Adu, 2014). Appadurai (2016) reminds us of the academic digital divide and the inherent inequality of scholars. For the future leaders of this unequal world, critical reasoning becomes a key skill, and perhaps especially so for students in the Global South. This paper argues that digital humanities (DH) can provide both a theoretical framework for decolonizing the academy and technological solutions to hurdles in this process in the Global South.1

The classroom interventions drawn on for this paper were implemented at liberal arts college Ashesi University2 located in the village of Berekuso in the peri-urban Eastern Region of Ghana. Its student body is intentionally diverse: geographically Pan-African with students from Southern, Eastern, and Western Africa, with a handful of exchange students from the Global North; economically diverse with 50% of students on scholarship and the other half full fee paying, and equal numbers of men to women. The philosophy behind the 16-years young university is training ethical leaders for the continent in engineering, business, and computer science, but with a broadly defined liberal arts foundation of Written and Oral Communication, Mathematics, Statistics, Programming, English Literature, Social Sciences, Statistics, and Leadership. All students, regardless of major, are taking this liberal arts core (Grant, 2016). Private-run Ashesi University features a relatively small classroom with a maximum of eighty students compared to the state universities where classes of several hundred are common. This classroom with students from more than twenty African nations is also more diverse. Still, it is a relevant experience as a laboratory as many other African universities on the continent today are having conversations on decolonizing the curriculum, see for instance Arukwe (2014) on teaching emancipatory postcolonial knowledge in Nigeria, Morreira (2015) on decolonizing the humanities in South Africa, and Nyamnjoh (2019) on decolonizing the African university as a whole. However, these conversations are rarely paired with new possibilities opened by low cost, accessible digital tools.

This paper seeks to present the theoretical underpinnings of selected Ashesi University interventions with DH pedagogy as well as give a practical account of how we created accessible technology-driven assignments that contributed to a more critical and perhaps even decolonial way of thinking for our students.

The term DH has been a quagmire to define. This ‘multifarious emerging field’ very broadly exists in ‘the intersection between humanities and information technology or the digital’ (Svensson, 2010). However, some issues that continuously seem to reoccur in the intersection argue Sayers (2018) in the introduction to the Routledge Companion to Media Studies and DH are the following; Beyond Text—or using ‘an array of media’ (p. 3), Labs and Collaborations—using experiments and developing methods, Social Justice—addressing issues of power and oppression, and Expanding Participation—beyond the usual departments of media studies and programming. Therefore, there is an element of activism pushing the boundaries of the academy built into the DH concept which was relevant to our classroom at Ashesi University where all Sayers’ DH dimensions were applicable, perhaps especially using experiments as well as addressing social justice.
div.h2: 3 Practise of DH and Decolonization in the Global South Classroom
div.p: A major academic debate the last few years in the Global South and beyond has been how to decolonize the curriculum. To act on this critique there are a number of possible paths. Breaking away from the Northern centric canon and reading Southern scholars (Connell, 2007) especially breaking free from epistemic theory being created in the Global North to explain subjects in the Global South (Grosfoguel, 2011), but also to reclaim subjectivity and humanity as individuals (Omarjee, 2018). Feminist scholar bell hooks (2009), has argued for an ‘engaged pedagogy’ that relies more on community and emotions than what is common in university. Educationists Freire and Macedo (2000) put the student at centre-stage and oppose the idea that students are not knowledgeable. This makes the students themselves not just actors, but possible material in the classroom. Moreover, educationist Sefa Dei (2009) has argued that there is a way of teaching Africa that is distinctly different from teaching elsewhere, which is paying more attention to indigenous knowledge as well as ‘knowledge anchored in African people’s aspirations, concerns and needs’ (p. xxi).

In DH, the focus on technology has been seen as particularly western and in need of critical examination (Bailey, 2011; Gallon, 2016; Risam, 2016; Noble, 2019; Rosino, 2019). Risam (2016) cautions that a global DH ‘requires reflection on plurality of circumstances’ (p. 4) and advocates for more localized DH beyond the US and Canada classroom. Within this context, practises of decolonizing DH have been put forward: Dutta (2019) highlights the importance of locally built applications for local relevance, Gil and Ortega (2016) suggest self-reflexivity, especially concerning language use and translations. Risam (2018) suggests centring indigenous knowledge and epistemology and writing back to dominant narratives. Common for all of these scholars is the core of critique—linking DH for the Global South with Critical Theory and Feminist Intersectionality.

As the decolonization of the academy requires rethinking everything from textbooks, content (local, indigenous, reflexive, etc.), language, role of students and lecturers as well as, importantly, assumptions we all bring into the classroom, I argue the assignments we ascribe must also necessarily change to fit this new paradigm.
div.h2: 4 Accessible Assignments: DH Pedagogy in a Diverse Classroom
div.p: In this section, three assignments are described where DH pedagogy like Wikipedia editing, Virtual Reality (VR), and WhatsApp was used. The first example is discussed most in detail as the author of this article was directly involved with designing and teaching the module. I will briefly discuss how each of the tools was used and then comment on learning gained from each approach.

The aim of this writing assignment was to deepen students’ research skills and create output adding to the knowledge body on Africa, as well as let the students gain a sense of what it is like to create knowledge for global consumption. Consequently, I decided to teach students how to edit and contribute to Wikipedia. The Social Theory core social science class was chosen for the pilot in the Spring of 2017. Comparable projects have been carried out in the region, see for instance Haslam (2017) who from his experience in the Gambia argues ‘The Wiki article assignment forces the student out of … . familiar habits and into a more cognitively challenging effort at neutrality, fairness, and some measure of objectivity and impartiality’ (p. 249) In his account of creating a similar assignment for students in Senegal, he stresses the fact that the assignment text is not just for the instructor, but also a possible lasting text with a global audience.

After completing an initial training on Wikimedia carried out by the Wikipedia Education Program,3 students read, found gaps in, and edited Wikipedia articles relevant to the class topics. This assignment was chosen in the context of developing our social science core course into a more critical application of ideas, especially those affecting the Global South such as inequality, religion, race, and privilege, building on not just textbooks and materials presented in class, but importantly also students’ own experiences and emotional engagement—an exercise in ‘writing back to dominant narratives’ as suggested by Risam (2018). The social science course focused heavily on the historical lives of black peoples and pre-colonial times, the transatlantic slave trade, as well as more contemporary issues such as #BlackLivesMatter. Within this course context, students chose to add to Wiki articles on topics such as Slave Forts in Ghana, but also created new pages about various Africa-related topics such as high schools in Kenya. Another group edited the page on the Origins of Twerking and an article on #MeToo around the World.

The assignment was found to be impactful in many ways; creating research skills, critical thinking, as well providing an experience of digital knowledge production. Importantly, in all groups, diversity was an asset as it allowed the students to think more broadly about ‘their’ issue and draft a better article. Thus, in 2018, the assignment was expanded to cover more class time.

In the French as a Foreign Language class, one module was devoted to travel and students ‘traveled’ to foreign places using VR technology. Students took turns using the phone holder (a box of twenty units for USD 20 each had been acquired by the university) with a student smartphone running a VR app inside (the basic Google CardBoard app was used), allowing them to ‘visit’ other places.

This experimental assignment added excitement to the class, it was useful for practicing vocabulary, and it was accessible as it was less formal and students used their own, or peers’, smartphones. Even so, we can reflect on what VR materials are available and which are produced in the Global South. In addition, the conversations on travel and restrictions on travel when holding a passport from the Global South were both centred and overcome at once using the power of the tool.

For the African Philosophical Thought elective, a WhatsApp list was created where students either use their smartphones or a friend’s smartphone to join the pre-class conversation group and share ideas on a specific weekly topic. WhatsApp was chosen as it is a tool used by most students. In a study by Adu-Kumi (2016), 84% of university students in Ghana used WhatsApp. After starting the topic, the lecturer would give over the space to students and only later add comments and questions. Students were also asked to contribute discussion questions and commented frequently. The tool allowed for broader participation than if they would have been an ordinary classroom discussion and encouraged submissions based on personal experience. In subsequent iterations of the class, questions the students posted to the group were graded on a scale reflecting actual engagement with the topics and texts. Using WhatsApp in the university setting connects the student to the immense popularity of the app in Africa and builds a community around the course, creating a new centre of knowledge.

All these three assignments are experimental in nature as well as examples of accessible DH pedagogy that seeks to rethink the group itself as diverse knowledge producers, rather than unknowledgeable students. While these trials were largely successful, in the next section, I summarize the various challenges and corresponding opportunities.
div.h2: 5 Challenges and Opportunities in Using DH Pedagogies
div.p: Teaching a diverse group of students can be both challenging and rewarding. Using digital tools can exacerbate differences if relying heavily on hardware (not everyone owns a smartphone, for instance), but it can also allow for a level playing field where the technology allows us to focus on ideas and shared experiences rather than on social status or diversity of individuals. In the Social Theory Wikipedia assignment, few students had edited Wiki before and the experience became a shared one. In the French class, the scarcity of smartphones and phone holders to create a VR experience in relation to the number of students in the classroom was an advantage as this situation naturally necessitated describing what could be seen in the VR world to fellow students.

Another potential problem for technology to challenge the lopsided knowledge production in the world is that all the apps and technologies discussed here derive from the Global North. Nevertheless, in all of these three cases, our students in Ghana have also not just used the technology in the classroom, but adopted it and developed it. After the first Wiki session in 2017, students set up their own Ashesi Wiki Club4 to continue creating knowledge, primarily in articles concerning the African continent. We had a student-led VR group meeting biweekly which transformed into at least two VR companies run by alumni developing the technology further.5 Future research on DH on the African continent, could further examine the actual process of Wiki, VR, and social media in creating learning gains, or describe local applications of digital technologies, a recent example being a region of Ghana that employed WhatsApp lists to coordinate maternal health, reducing mortality (Ghana News Association, 2018).

The three assignments at Ashesi University using DH pedagogy discussed in this paper all empower students with knowledge and tools that give them agency, moving away from a passive absorption of texts written in the Global North, modelling inclusive lifelong learning built around our local experience, celebrating and using diversity rather than problematizing it, hence decolonizing the classroom.

While DH allows for increased participation, the framework is still, ironically, not local. It is worth noting the digital tools I discuss here are all developed in the Global North. Never the less, I argue DH can empower and decolonize the classroom if the pedagogy:

li.p: Creates a level playing field and shared experience in a group, by creating assignments mindful of the diversity and inequalities present.
Challenges central texts produced in the Global North as sole repositories of knowledge.
Engages students by introducing accessible DH tools for producing knowledge.
